answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
Making changes to benefit plans (i.e. increasing deductibles, offering two or more plans for employees, increasing co-pays, etc.) have helped in the short-term for communities I've worked in, but employee wellness is the best long-term solution.  Unfortunately, we're a "what have you done for me lately?" culture that can't sit around and wait for the 3-5 year ROI that wellness programs offer, so when it comes to cutting budgets, those programs are usually on the chopping block and get the axe before they've had time to develop.  
We're just starting a wellness program in our organization and in our community, and I'd love to see some responses here from cities who have had wellness programs in place for 5+ years and can demonstrate the value that they bring to lowering long-term health care costs.  Thanks for the question, Alex.

answers.author: Amanda Dodge
answers.text:
Hi Alex,
Wake County, North Carolina was nominated for ICMA's Strategic Leadership and Governance Award in 2010 for their wellness program. Their program incorporates onsite wellness programs with insurance-based health and wellness benefits. Some of their programs include lifestyle management classes, incentive-based annual health risk assessments and “Know Your Numbers” screening, and onsite employee health services.  Not only did the number of prescriptions for cholesterol and anti-depressants drop, but after the first year there was only a 7% rate increase (as opposed to double digits in previous years) and a 4% increase the second year. Here is the link to the full nomination document:
http://bit.ly/lJWECX
Hope this helps!
Amanda Dodge

ICMA is in the process of conducting a national survey of local government employee health insurance benefits. Included in the survey are questions about cost reduction strategies. We anticipate receiving some excellent examples of steps local governments have taken, which will be shared in PM magazine articles and other publications. The summary results will be made available on the ICMA website, and a session will be held at the ICMA Annual Conference.

Evelina – in this month’s Washoe County, NV Community newsletter there is an article re: Employee Health Care Costs Virtually Unchanged - County Commissioners approved an employee health benefit program for 2011-12 that holds employee health care costs at virtually no increase compared to the previous year. This accomplishment is significant given that employee health care coverage was estimated to increase as much as 12% over the previous year`s. Through negotiations, employees voluntarily agreed to increase their out-of-pocket deductibles and co-pays.

author: Alex Brown
text: Providing health insurance to employees and retirees continues to increase in cost. Local governments across the country are taking steps to control these rising costs by implementing employee wellness programs and increasing employee deductibles and co-payments. What changes has your government made to its health insurance programs to keep costs down?
title: Controlling the Cost of Health Insurance
